title: The Birth and Early Life of Moses
shortSummary: Exodus chapter 2 recounts the birth of Moses, his preservation by Pharaoh's daughter, and his early years including his flight to Midian. This chapter sets the stage for God's deliverance of Israel by highlighting His providential care and faithfulness to His covenant people.
timeline: c. 1446 BC - The Early Life of Moses during Israel's bondage in Egypt

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: A Levite child born during Israel's oppression in Egypt, who is preserved by Pharaoh's daughter and later becomes Israel's deliverer.

keyCharacters.name: Pharaoh's Daughter
keyCharacters.description: The Egyptian princess who rescues Moses from the Nile, raises him as her son, and unknowingly preserves God's chosen deliverer.

keyCharacters.name: Moses' Sister
keyCharacters.description: Likely Miriam, she watches over Moses after he is placed in the river and arranges for their mother to nurse him.

keyCharacters.name: Reuel (Jethro)
keyCharacters.description: The priest of Midian who becomes Moses' father-in-law after Moses helps his daughters at a well.

definitions.definition: A small basket or box made from papyrus reeds, waterproofed with pitch and slime, used to protect baby Moses in the river.
One of the twelve sons of Jacob; the tribe of Levi was set apart for priestly duties and religious service.
A region east of Egypt where Moses fled after killing the Egyptian; home to the descendants of Abraham through Keturah.
A woman who breastfeeds and cares for an infant; Moses' mother served as his nurse after Pharaoh's daughter arranged it.

outline.heading: The Birth and Preservation of Moses
outline.description: Moses is born to a Levite family and hidden for three months to protect him from Pharaoh’s decree. When he can no longer be hidden, his mother places him in a waterproof basket in the Nile, where Pharaoh’s daughter finds and adopts him, unknowingly preserving God's chosen deliverer.

outline.heading: Moses' Early Compassion and Flight
outline.description: As a grown man, Moses witnesses the oppression of his people and kills an Egyptian who was beating a Hebrew. Fearing Pharaoh’s wrath, Moses flees Egypt, marking a turning point in his life and God’s plan.

outline.heading: Moses in Midian
outline.description: Moses helps the daughters of Reuel, the Midianite priest, and is invited to dwell with their family. He marries Zipporah and has a son, symbolizing his new life in exile.

outline.heading: God’s Faithfulness to Israel
outline.description: Despite Israel’s suffering under bondage, God hears their cries and remembers His covenant with the patriarchs, demonstrating His ongoing commitment to deliver His people.

application: Trust in God's providence even in difficult and uncertain circumstances, as He is always working to fulfill His promises.
Show compassion and courage in standing for justice, following Moses’ example of concern for his oppressed brethren.
Be willing to step into new seasons of life with faith, trusting God’s guidance as Moses did when he fled to Midian.
Remember that God hears the cries of His people and remains faithful to His covenant, encouraging persistent prayer and hope.

keyVerses.text: And the child grew, and she brought him unto Pharaoh's daughter, and he became her son. And she called his name Moses: and she said, Because I drew him out of the water.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God's providential preservation of Moses, whose name and life symbolize deliverance.

keyVerses.text: And it came to pass in process of time, that the king of Egypt died: and the children of Israel sighed by reason of the bondage, and they cried, and their cry came up unto God by reason of the bondage.
keyVerses.significance: It shows that God hears the suffering of His people and sets the stage for their deliverance.

keyVerses.text: And God looked upon the children of Israel, and God had respect unto them.
keyVerses.significance: This verse affirms God's compassion and faithfulness to His covenant people despite their oppression.
